user.biography: History isn't made by kings or politicians, it is made by us: billions of ordinary people ✊ podcast | social | patreon | store

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
On this day, 17 August 1909, Indian revolutionary Madan Lal Dhingra was executed by the British for his assassination of Sir Curzon Wyllie, an army officer and head of the secret police, who was trying to uncover and defeat anti-colonial activists. While Dhingra was supported by anarchist Guy Aldred, who was sentenced to 12 months' hard labour for publishing a sympathetic article about him, Mohandas Gandhi condemned him. On trial, he refused to acknowledge the authority of the court, and stated "I hold the English people responsible for the murder of eighty millions of Indian people in the last fifty years, and they are also responsible for taking away ₤100,000,000 every year from India to this country." 
Learn more about resistance to the British Empire in this book: https://shop.workingclasshistory.com/products/insurgent-empire-anticolonial-resistance-and-british-dissent-priyamvada-gopal
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and people standing.

node.text:
On this day, 16 August 1972, women cleaners at the Ministry of Defence in London won a strike which began in July for a payrise and union recognition, in what would become a watershed moment in the "Night Cleaners Campaign". 
The mostly Caribbean and Irish cleaners were supported by the women's movement, who jointly set up picket lines 24 hours a day, as well as by other workers. May Hobbs, one of the strikers, recalled in her autobiography, Born to Struggle: "[post office] engineers stopped servicing their telephones, the dustmen left their bins full, no mail went in and there were no deliveries of bread, milk or beer to the canteen."
The workers won an increase in basic pay of over 30%, to £6.50 per week, plus a 50p night allowance, as well as an agreement of no victimisation for participants in the strike.
*
We only post highlights on here, for all our anniversaries follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/wrkclasshistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and crowd.

node.text:
On this day, 16 August 2012, police in South Africa massacred thirty-four miners who were on a wildcat strike fighting for a pay increase at the Marikana mine operated by the British platinum company Lonmin. Seventy-eight others were injured in a violent attack by security forces, which the African National Congress government falsely claimed was an act of self-defence on the part of the police. It was the worst violence by security forces in the country since the days of apartheid. A few days prior, officials in the National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) had opened fire on the striking workers-mostly their own members - leaving two critically injured. 
This is a history of the strike wave and the repression: https://libcom.org/library/south-africa-partial-reemergence-workers-autonomy-mouvement-communiste-kolektivn%C4%9B-proti
Pictured: Marikana miners on strike

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 15, 2021.

node.text:
On this day, 16 August 1819, the Peterloo massacre took place when British cavalry charged into a crowd of between 60,000 and 80,000 working class people demanding the right to vote for men. 15 were murdered and up to 700 injured. 
Learn more in our podcast episode 19 about the massacre featuring Mike Leigh, director of the 2018 film, Peterloo: https://workingclasshistory.com/2018/11/07/e15-the-peterloo-massacre-with-mike-leigh/

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people.

node.text:
On this day, 15 August 1918, Mexican anarchist Ricardo Flores Magón, of Zapotec descent, began a 21-year prison sentence at the McNeil Island penitentiary in Washington for mail and espionage violations. He was later transferred to the Leavenworth penitentiary in Kansas, where he died in 1922, following months of illness and neglect. 
Flores Magón was a founding member of the anarchist Partido Liberal Mexicano (Mexican Liberal Party; PLM), and important theoretician of the Mexican revolution which began in 1910. In the early days of the revolution, when Francisco Madero emerged as the leading candidate to replace dictator Porfirio Díaz, Flores Magón and his comrades attempted to warn the working class that swapping leaders would not necessarily improve their lot: "Governments have to protect the right of property above all other rights. Do not expect then, that Madero will attack the right of property in favour of the working class. Open your eyes. Remember a phrase, simple and true and as truth indestructible, the emancipation of the workers must be the work of the workers themselves".
Here is a short biography: https://libcom.org/history/magon-ricardo-flores-1873-1922

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
On this day, 15 August 1970, Black Panther Party co-founder Huey P Newton delivered a speech in New York City where he criticised the previous attitude of the party, and other left groups towards women and LGBT+ people. 
He criticised homophobia and sexism in revolutionary movements, commenting that "homosexuals… might be the most oppressed people in… society", and called on the left to desist using homophobic language to describe "enemies of the people" like president Richard Nixon. He argued that all radical events should include "full participation of the gay liberation movement and the women's liberation movement". 
The move came after the foundation of the Gay Liberation Front, which supported the Black liberation movement, and militantly raised issues such as homophobia within radical organisations. 
We discuss that in our podcast episodes 25-26 about the GLF and the Stonewall rebellion: https://workingclasshistory.com/2019/05/13/e21-22-the-stonewall-riots-and-pride-at-50/

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
On 17 August 1945, nationalist leaders in Indonesia declared independence following the defeat of Japan in World War II. The Netherlands, which had previously occupied the country for 350 years, promptly re-invaded and spent the next four years engaged in a brutal war to reconquer its former colony. Perversely, they attempted to justify their invasion as a continuation of the WWII fight for "democracy" against Japanese fascism. Dutch forces were backed up by 30,000 British troops (mostly from India), and they killed up to 100,000 Indonesian fighters as well as tens of thousands of civilians, many of them in mass, summary executions. There were also conflicts within the nationalist ranks: when an Indonesian Soviet Republic was declared by socialists and communists in 1948 it was quickly suppressed by the nationalists, and its leader killed. Eventually, despite a string of military victories by the colonists, by 1949 they were forced to grant Indonesian independence.
Pictured: Independence being declared
*
We only post highlights on here, for all our anniversaries follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/wrkclasshistory

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 14, 2021.

node.text:
On this day, 14 August 1945 the August Revolution began in Vietnam against the French colonial regime. Within two weeks the insurgency had been successful across the whole country, and Vietnam announced on 2 September a Declaration of Independence, based on that of the United States in 1776: "All men are created equal. They are endowed by their Creator with certain inalienable rights; among these are Life, Liberty, and the pursuit of Happiness." However the US was not happy about this. They funded French efforts to retake the country, and later invaded themselves. 
We have produced an extensive podcast series about US intervention in Vietnam and opposition to it which you can find here on our website: https://workingclasshistory.com/tag/vietnam-war
Pictured: a scene from the August Revolution

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 14, 2021.

node.text:
On this day, 14 August 1889, the great London dock strike began when workers at West India Dock walked out and called on others to join them. Within two weeks 130,000 were out and dockers' wives organised a rent strike for the duration of the stoppage. 
Other workers like Jewish tailors walked out with their own demands. Australian dockers donated money to support their UK colleagues, and after four weeks the employers caved and agreed nearly all the workers' demands. 
The men had been inspired by the strike of "match girls" at Bryant & May the previous year. The dispute marked a turning point in British working class history, as disorganised casual workers like the dockers were inspired to organise themselves and start to win. 
This is a short history of the struggle: https://libcom.org/history/1889-the-great-london-dock-strike

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text: On this day, 14 August 1944, 29-year-old Italian resistance partisan Irma Bandiera, aka 'Mimma', was murdered by the Nazis. They had blinded her and tortured her for seven days, however she refused to give up the names of her comrades. Her body was then dumped in the street outside her parents' house. Today there is a street named after her in her native Bologna.

node.text:
Behind the scenes we've been working on turning our global archive of nearly 4000 historical events into a powerful, interactive, free website with browsable timelines and maps, and sources. We need your help to make this a reality, so please consider donating or sharing this appeal. Learn more and donate here: https://www.gofundme.com/f/help-us-build-a-web-app
To access this hyperlink, click our link in bio, swipe left then click this photo.
Pictured is a draft beta version of the map feature

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Working Class History on August 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
On this day, 13 August 1880, suffragette and union organiser Mary Macarthur was born in Glasgow. She founded the National Federation of Women Workers, and led a strike of 2,000 women across London in the summer of 1911. 
Macarthur was a leading figure in the working class wing of the suffragette movement. As such she opposed World War I, and opposed voting rights being given just to wealthy women, which made her unpopular with middle class suffragettes. The middle class wing of the movement aimed to achieve voting rights only for property owning women.
Pictured: Macarthur addressing striking workers
